Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Development of a Multivariate Biomarker Analysis Technique for Paleoclimate Reconstruction
Award.AbstractNarration:
Reconstructions of past environments based on chemical "proxies" have provided invaluable insights into how the Earth system functions on a variety of timescales, from decades to millions of years. Organic molecular, or "biomarker", proxies are being applied increasingly in paleoclimate studies, and these compounds hold a wealth of information about an array of environmental conditions includin temperature, aridity, vegetation biome type, and water salinity. However, their current interpretation is mainly in terms of a single variable of interest, most often temperature.

This study, led by an early-career researcher from the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, is a first attempt to leverage the multidimensional quality of biomarker data for paleoclimate reconstruction. A statistical model will be developed using artificial neural network (ANN) and support vector regression (SVR) algorithms ("machine learning" techniques). This will allow quantitative evaluation of how assemblages of biomarkers in sedimentary archives relate to an array of modern environmental conditions. The outcomes of the proposed project will include development of a new toolbox to quantitatively reconstruct past climates over land and in the ocean in many types of paleoclimate archives. Such a tool could have broad application across a range of fields including environmental studies, petroleum geology, and computer science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
"Paleoclimate" refers to the study of past climates and environments throughout Earth history. To figure out what sort of climate changes took place in the past, paleoclimatologists measure different chemical and physical indicators in sedimentary deposits, like rock outcrops and marine cores collected from the bottom of the sea. Typically, paleoclimatologists focus on one indicator or perhaps a small subset of indicators. However, there are potentially thousands of chemical signatures recorded in the rock record, and many of them reflect environmental change.

The purpose of this project was to investigate whether tapping into the multidimensionality of the paleoclimate record can expand our ability to infer past climate change. We took the approach of using organic geochemistry - e.g., the measuring the large array of organic molecules that are found in sediments. Many of the molecules, called "biomarkers" are already powerful indicators of past temperature, for example. But, it is possible that we have overlooked other compounds that may additionally shed light on past ocean productivity, salinity, or rainfall. By measuring as many biomarkers as possible in 300 samples, we created a comprehensive database of naturally occuring compounds in the modern marine and near shore environment.

To discover whether the high-dimensional biomarker dataset encodes environmental information, we are currently applying modern machine learning techniques to our database. These techniques include support vector machines, artifical neural networks, and random forests and are similar to the types of classification techniques that are used in internet search engines, for example. There have not been many applications of these techniques to paleoclimate to date, so this project is novel in terms of employing concepts from modern computer science.

Proof-of-concept of this method is ongoing, but this NSF award helped kick-start what we hope to be a useful way of identifying and classifying paleoenvironments. In addition to applications in paleoclimatology, this could also be useful to mining or petroleum industries interested in what past depositional environments looked like.
